Posts.Content: I'm fairly new to the forum and by no means an expert, but your situation is very similar to my significant other's. He was noted to have an elevated PSA (7, in his case) on a routine screening at the age of 37 - no symptoms at all, though he does have a family history of prostate cancer. He had a biopsy about six months later, as the PSA remained elevated and even climbed a bit on repeat tests, in spite of antibiotics. The biopsy at that time was negative, though his urologist cautioned him that false negatives are sadly not uncommon in early-stage disease. Everyone said, of course, that he was far too young for PCa to be at all likely - probably just prostatitis, or some other benign issue. His PSA continued to rise steadily over the next five years, and he finally had a saturation biopsy this past May - positive for cancer, Gleason score 7. He is 42 years old now, very young for PCa. We assume that the cancer was present five years ago and was simply missed on the biopsy, and had in fact likely been there for quite a while prior to that considering his initial PSA of 7. He is being treated now and we are hopeful that everything will turn out positively - but in retrospect, I think we both wish that we had taken things more seriously and pursued an answer five years ago. Your situation may turn out to be very different, of course! I sincerely hope so. But be careful of falling into the trap of assuming that it surely can't be cancer because of your age, and allowing a negative biopsy to give you a false sense of security. I've since learned that so called "blind" biopsies have a distressingly high incidence of false negatives. This may be where you need to start, but if it doesn't show anything, I would strongly urge you to pursue further testing - 3T MRI, possible saturation biopsy, etc. If needed, it may even be worth getting a second opinion from one of the top cancer centers on how to proceed if your initial biopsy is negative. I know that Duke, for example, prides itself on being able to find PCa if it's there - even if previous biopsies, etc. have been negative or inconclusive. My takeaway from our experience has been that if your PSA is suspiciously high for no good reason, even if you're quite young, cancer is very much on the table. Better to find it now, than later. Best wishes, and I hope you're able to get some answers.
Posts.Signature: (Posting for my significant other) First PSA in early 2012, at age 37: 7 Retested 6 months later: 9 Biopsy performed August 2012, 13 cores: negative PSA continued to climb slowly from 2012 to 2017 3T MRI performed in March 2017: no abnormalities PSA April 2017: 19 Saturation biopsy May 2017: 2 of 22 cores positive, Gleason 7 (4+3) Bone scan June 2017: negative Nerve-sparing robotic prostatectomy June 28, 2017 Catheter removed 5 days post-op, acute urinary retention 48 hours later - second catheter placed in emergency room. Second catheter removed 10 days later, no further retention issues. Post-op pathology: Gleason upgraded to 8 (3+5) with extracapsular extension and positive surgical margins.

Posts.Title: Prostate biopsy at 32

Posts.Content: An update on my SO: We met with the surgeon today to get the post-op pathology results. Unfortunately, the news was not as good as we had hoped - Gleason score was upgraded to 8 (3+5), with extracapsular extension and positive surgical margins on the anterior aspect. Based on these findings, the surgeon said that SO will almost certainly need follow-up radiation, but that we don't need to do anything right now until his first post-op PSA check in October. Assuming that there is still a detectable level at that point, they would recommend starting radiation treatment. We are still wrapping our heads around this news, since we had really hoped that the surgery would be curative - or at least, would buy him several years before any follow-up treatment might be needed. Any words of advice or encouragement would be welcome We are concerned about what kinds of side effects to expect with the radiation treatment, so any thoughts on that from those who have been there would be great. He's understandably very worried about long-term urinary continence, ED, etc. - especially since those things had just started to improve from surgery. And of course, we have even greater worries about what this may mean for long-term prognosis, given that he's only 42. Today's news was definitely a blow to morale.

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: Thanks to both of you for your replies! MM, you are correct - final Gleason score 8, stage T3a. Sampled lymph nodes and seminal vesicles were negative. SO did have blood drawn today for a PSA, which the surgeon said was just to give us a general idea of where things were headed and give us something recent to compare to in October. We specifically asked if anything needed to be started right now, treatment-wise - he said that radiation would not be started until 3 months post-op, at the earliest. Have you heard or read differently as far as the typical timeline? From the research I've done so far, I suspected that the G5 component would probably increase the overall risk of metastasis. I assume that this, in addition to the general Gleason score of 8 and positive margins, is a pretty good argument for adjuvant radiation therapy regardless of what the PSA in October shows... but would certainly welcome any thoughts on that. I did wonder if perhaps we should go ahead and schedule an initial consultation with an RO - since it sounds very likely that we'll be needing one, and it's probably better to go ahead and get established so that we can hit the ground running when the time comes.

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: Also, one other question for anyone who might have thoughts. The surgeon indicated that it doesn't really make much difference who we choose for the radiation treatment, since for adjuvant or salvage radiation the entire prostate bed and pelvic area are treated - as opposed to more targeted forms of radiation that would be used as a first-line treatment option, and which would also require more skill and experience to administer well. Essentially, he seemed to be saying that ART/SRT is pretty low tech and uncomplicated as far as technique goes, so one RO is as good as the next for this. Does anyone have any wisdom to offer on this? I know we're limited to using someone fairly local to our area regardless, since the treatments would be daily for 8 weeks - but beyond that, does it make a difference?

Posts.Title: pathology report - assuming radiation next?

Posts.Content: Well, it appears that I may have spoken too soon about things going well post-surgery. Went to the ER last night around midnight because SO was completely unable to urinate. ER had a former urology nurse on staff, fortunately, who was able to get another cath in without too much difficulty. SO is now back home and feeling much better, but with the dreaded urinary catheter back in place Has anyone here had experience with this complication? Truthfully, we didn't even know that this could happen - we were prepared for incontinence and ED, but had no idea that he could become obstructed like that and have to be re-cathed.

Posts.Content: I wondered about that as well. Five days post-op seemed awfully soon to remove it - but this guy has done thousands of prostatectomies, and he said five days was fine. But regardless, here we are I admit, I've been a bit frustrated that neither the surgeon nor the primary urologist has shown much interest in any of this, or bothered to talk to us about why this might have happened or whether we need to worry. This seems like an awful lot of complications, especially in a young and healthy guy with no other health issues at all.

Posts.Content: And yes, RobLee - you are correct. His surgery was just over a week ago. The catheter was removed on Monday, 5 days post-op. A cystogram was done at that time which showed no problems.

Posts.Title: Urinary retention post-op?

Posts.Content: Update - spoke to a nurse at the surgeon's office. Plan for now is to leave the catheter in place for another 10 days, then go back to their office on 7/17 for a recheck and another cystogram. No information on why this might have happened, or whether it's anything to worry about.

Posts.Title: Urinary retention post-op?

Posts.Content: And, another update... this has been a really terrific week, lol. As of today, he's been really uncomfortable and having extremely bloody urine. Urologist called in antibiotics for presumed UTI. Does anyone have any experience with this, at least? It seems that having to be re-cathed is pretty unusual, so of course we're concerned about that... but I'm assuming that UTIs with an indwelling urinary catheter are probably fairly common. Essentially, I think we're looking for some reassurance that this is all somewhat "par for the course" in terms of potential surgical complications, and not any reason to be unduly worried? It's been a tough few days, especially since we thought we were pretty much past the hard part once the catheter was removed last Monday. Hoping it will all be worth it in the end.

Posts.Title: Urinary retention post-op?

Posts.Content: We contacted his primary urologist as well as the surgeon last night before going to the ER. They didn't have much to say about it, except that he needed to go to the hospital for emergency catheterization. Have not heard anything else so far about what the plan is from here.

Posts.Title: Urinary retention post-op?

Posts.Content: Thanks for your perspective! We do realize, of course, that radiation has side effects as well. Based on our research so far, as well as anecdotal experiences from people we have spoken to, my impression is that surgery is all but certain to cause these side effects. Radiation can cause them also in a certain percentage of patients, but it seems that the degree can often be lessened as compared with a prostatectomy. There are also some other concerns which are more surgery-specific, in his case, which would be avoided with radiation. We know that surgery may ultimately be the only realistic choice. But we would like to hear more about radiation as an alternative, assuming localized disease only - particularly for someone so young.
Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Hi all, This is my first post on this forum, so it's very nice to meet you all - although I certainly wish I didn't need to be here! My significant other (SO) was diagnosed with prostate cancer via saturation biopsy on June 2nd. Needless to say, we are scared and a bit overwhelmed - it seems that PCa is quite a complex disease, with lots of factors to consider and a multitude of treatment options. I will fill in all of the relevant details later on when I have his biopsy report and records on-hand to look at, but a brief summary of where we are right now: SO is 42 years old, very active and in great shape. Otherwise healthy. He has a history of markedly elevated PSA levels dating back to 2012 - PSA was around 10 the first time it was checked, as I recall, at the age of 37. A biopsy was done in the fall of 2012, which was negative. PSAs have continued to rise steadily but gradually since then, to a level of 19 in March of this year. The saturation biopsy was done last week, and came back positive in 2 of 22 cores - both Gleason score 7 (4+3). He had a contrast MRI done in March which included the prostate and pelvic region, which showed no evidence of any problems. DREs have been consistently normal, and still are. The urologist says that based on what we know right now, SO is staged as T1c and he believes that the cancer is confined to the prostate. My understanding of all this is that, although a Gleason score of 4+3 indicates a moderately aggressive cancer, we have a good chance of a cure if all goes well with treatment. I'm sure that we will have many questions over the next few weeks (thanks in advance for your patience!), but right now, the main one is this. Our urologist indicated that surgery would be highly recommended as the best option in SO's case. This does seem to be the most common approach that I have seen for PCa that is presumed to be localized, and I believe we understand the major "pros" of that approach - including post-op pathology analysis for a better picture of the situation, more options for secondary treatment later on if the cancer recurs, etc. The problem is, SO is vehemently opposed to surgery unless there are truly no other viable options. While I think that I would probably choose surgery if it were me, I do understand his reasons and believe that they are valid and well thought-out. Mainly, he is concerned about serious, possibly permanent side effects (incontinence, ED, etc.) that may severely impact his quality of life. These are crappy side effects to deal with at any age, but I can sympathize with the fact that they are especially hard to handle at 42. From our research, it seems that radiation and surgery have fairly comparable long-term "cure" rates for localized PCa in many cases. He is very interested in radiation therapy for his PCa, including a multi-modal approach with brachytherapy, IMRT, etc. if needed. We are meeting with a local radiation oncologist next week, and will also be seeking a second opinion at one of the major cancer treatment centers within the next few weeks, so hopefully they can shed some light on these options as well. But so far, everyone we have spoken to (both laypeople, and medical professionals) has said unequivocally that surgery is by far his best chance of a good long-term outcome. I would be very interested to hear from anyone here who chose radiation over surgery as a first-line treatment approach, including your reasons for the choice, how aggressive your cancer was, and what specific type of treatment plan was used. I would also love to know if you are happy with your decision, looking back, or if you ever wish you had chosen surgery instead. Any other general thoughts on radiation vs. surgery, especially in such a young patient, would also be very welcome.
Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Thanks for your perspective! We do realize, of course, that radiation has side effects as well. Based on our research so far, as well as anecdotal experiences from people we have spoken to, my impression is that surgery is all but certain to cause these side effects. Radiation can cause them also in a certain percentage of patients, but it seems that the degree can often be lessened as compared with a prostatectomy. There are also some other concerns which are more surgery-specific, in his case, which would be avoided with radiation. We know that surgery may ultimately be the only realistic choice. But we would like to hear more about radiation as an alternative, assuming localized disease only - particularly for someone so young.
